Smoothing out the machined "roughness" on the blade holder is a mistake. See 3:02 (where you remove the blade) and 7:10 where you flatten, smooth and polish surface. The surface was machined to be rough to aid in keeping the blade in place and prevent it from slipping. With a smooth polished surface, all of the "friction" creaed by the machined roughness is gone and the full force of the pressure on the blade when cutting, is now transfered to the 3 small bolts holding the blade in place. Whilst the finished item looks brilliant, I think you will find that it will work slightly less well than the original because of that.
